You remembered the orc costume you saw on the way into the shop and how cool it was. It would be best to try to find something like that so you could keep it simple enough to wear out in public for a laugh. You told Zorgo.

"How about something humanoid?"

"Ah of course!" he said loudly, "That's everyone's first time choice! Now how about that blood elf costume I mentioned? I believe I still have one in female."

"Hmm." you thought aloud.
11221.title: Humanoid selection.

choices: Try on the blood elf suit
112211.content:
"Sure, I'll give it a try." you said.

"You are lucky! These blood elf suits are in high demand these days! Must be the need for spies, or something." said Zorgo.

After a few minutes he comes back with a flesh colored roll. " My last one. All yours, for the right price." he says like a true salesman.

You look at the roll as he unrolls it. A flat naked female blood elf is revealed. It had blond "hair" on it. Almost like yourself, except for the hair color and pointy ears,

"Are you sure I can fit in that? I think I'm gonna break it." You say nervously.

"My dear, that's what they all say before they try it. There are rooms in the back for trying costumes on. How about it?
112211.title: Sure, why not?

choices: "Yes, and do you have anymore I can look at?"
1122111.content:
"Well, I guess you should try anything once." You said, holding up the blood elf costume. It's flattened eyeless face was starting to creep you out.

"That's the spirit!" Chirped Zorgo. "Here, step into the changing rooms. You can pay once you're satisfied!"

"Once I'm satisfied, huh?" You thought to yourself as the gnome led you to one of the changing rooms in the back of the shop. It was small and dainty, dust was everywhere as well much like the rest of the store. Zorgo apparently didn't believe in living clean.

You sighed, questioning why you even bothered to try this. You hated costume, even if there was a bit of magic in this it probably wouldn't be that believable. But you couldn't just walk out now, you became stripping yourself naked.

The suit wasn't exactly large, as you had pointed out before. Though you were on the short side yourself, there would be no way you could fit into this thing, it looked like it was meant for a child. There didn't appear to be any entrances either other then the mouth.

"Here goes nothing..." You muttered, sticking one foot inside the costume.

Strangely enough, the insides were warm and smooth much like actual skin. You discovered something else as well, the suit stretched like rubber. Effortlessly, you slid your legs inside until they rested comfortably in their appropriate areas of the costume. You wiggled your toes for good measure and looked down, a pair of tiny red toe nail painted toes wiggled back in response.

It was like stepping into a sack almost, you pulled the suit further and further up your body. Every corner seemed to rest comfortably on top of your body, you eventually reached the arms. With one hand, you held open the mouth of the suit and stuck the other arm inside, doing the same once the first arm was safely aligned.

Then came the head. Putting it on was like wearing a cowl, you grabbed the lower portion of the 'mouth' and pulled the top over your face. Everything went dark slightly as you realigned your eyes with the suit's sockets. The mouth of the suit apparently stuck on top of your own, as it didn't come lose when you released it.

Stepping back slightly, you got a good look at yourself in the nearby mirror.

"Wow..." You said. The costume was flawless...You were at a complete lose for words. It really looked like there was a real actual blood elf standing in the changing room, even your eyes had begun to give an eerie greenish glow.

"Everything to your satisfaction, miss?" Called out Zorgo with a slightly smug tone.

"Yes...Wow...This is incredible...Is this magic?"

"Only the finest, my dear. Are you still interested in purchasing it?"
1122111.title: Testing the blood elf suit.

11221111.content:
You flexed your fingers slightly, you couldn't even feel your real hand moving around under the suit's skin. It was like this was your new hand, your new body. The possibilities for this were simply...Endless.

"Yes..." You answered. "And do you have anymore I can look at?"

The gnome's eyes lit up. "Why of course! What sort of costume were you looking for?"

They were probably all really expensive, but your family wasn't a part of Stormwind's royal mages for nothing. You had the money to afford any price Zorgo could throw at you. The question was, what suited your fancy exactly? The possibilities were truly endless.

"I'll take..."
11221111.title: Getting more.

112211111.content:
"I'll take one of everything" you called back from the booth, the gold coins in your purse could even buy Zorgo's entire stock if you wanted to.

A big grin covered Zorgo's face and he laughed maniacally as you finished your sentence. "Wonderful, wonderful! I've never met someone very attracted to my costumes except you, my young lady." He then continued, "Now if you'd just wait in that booth, I'll be back very soon with your orders."

You lightly strode in your new blood elf body. It's very similar to your old body, with a difference in the pointed ears and greenish glow that emanated from the eye sockets also a bit taller frame. However as you moved around, it was apparent that your new body is definitely more agile than your old one. You moved around the booth, which luckily didn't have too much visitors as most of the city's population would rather flock to the circus.

You put on your purple apprentice robe back and walked to the counter, where apparently had been laden out with various crumpled suits by Zorgo. Some you can recognize as human, tauren, dwarf and gnome. "Ah, I see you've taken a liking to that suit, but please take it off when you are inside the city." Zorgo advised you as he brought back a couple more suits from his stock.

"Why not? I saw an orc walking outside your store some time ago." you ask Zorgo. He just sighed, "Orc aren't exactly famous for their stealth or wit, so no orc would ever get into this kingdom and much less one walking without fear during the day. Blood elves however, are different, especially their rangers. You aren't exactly bright are you?" He finished with a chuckle.

Embarrassed by your question, you trudged back to the booth. "Now, to release the suit you need to use a bit of magic, but I guess it'll be easy for you." Zorgo called out. He then asked you to memorize an incantation. "To take it off, you must yank your hair hard and say the incantation, no need to be aloud, but must be audible to yourself." You did as you were told and found the suit was again a separate object from your body.

It was afternoon that finally your orders were completed. You saw the rays of sun setting from the glass window of the store. Aside from occasional oddballs peering from the front window, no one else entered the store. "I guess common people do not appreciate my genius work, it might be the last time I will join a fair here." Zorgo sighed again. As you moved to the counter, he gleamed, "So in here are the full package of every race in Azeroth, from each gender too!" He then gave a chuckle as he handed you a bag stuffed full of skin-like suits.

You paid the amount, and the sound of cash register ringed in the store. "Now allow me to present you with this, the latest work of Zorgo the Genius!" he boastfully self-proclaimed himself. You just looked at him quizzically as he brandished two sets of suits, however, these suits doesn't have any hair or any shape at all, save for an almost recognizable humanoid appearance.

Moments later you found yourself outside the store, Zorgo had explained how the suits would work, including the new ones and his address as well! Not that you're going to go there in any moment. It seemed to be near a mountain.

Now, with a bag full of suits, you walked back into your manor...
112211111.title: "One of everything."

112212.content:
"Do you have anything more unusual? It sounds like that kind of thing is a little common." You wanted a costume that would be an eye raiser. Zorgo seemed to understand what you were getting at.

"Ah of course, of course! You want something that will get you some attention! Well I have just the thing here. This one is a rare one, it's a tauren suit. My only female one as a matter of fact! Would you like to see it?"

You shrugged but said yes. The gnome disappeared to the back of the store returning with what looked like a brown furry blanket. He unraveled it on the ground like a carpet to show it to you. Sure enough, the mass of fur had hooves, a tail, and horns just like a tauren would. But the thing looked ridiculously big, there was no way you would be able to make a convincing tauren in that.

"So what do you say my girl? Interested?"

"Um...It looks way too big for me. Doesn't it?"

"Ah, but that is part of the magic of a Zorgo product! Trust me, you'll see if you put it on. What do you say?"
112212.title: Other humanoid suits.

choices: You get caught by guards while wandering around as a tauren.
You go to class like this.
1122121.content:
"Well..." you said outloud, "Why not? This could be good for a laugh or two right?"

"That's the spirit my girl! Now, I'll let you try it on in the back. There should be a changing booth there. Here you are."

He folded and handed the suit to you. You followed his instructions and went to the back of the shop. The booth was more like three boards stuck together with a curtain nailed to the front, but it was better than nothing. You began to unfold the costume and found it's face. You stared into the empty eye sockets and laughed. It looked like someone skinned a tauren and used it as a costume. But it was so warm too, it was like the skin was a living entity. You rolled your eyes at the thought of what Zorgo said. "That is part of the magic of a Zorgo product!"

"Hah, I can't sense anything magical about this thing. He definitely just skinned a poor tauren and is selling it as a costume." you told yourself.

But you couldn't help but feel an urge inside you to try and wear it. Maybe it was the same feeling of amazement and wonder you felt when you first learned about magic and mages as a child. You wanted to believe that this would work deep down, and unfortunately it was enough to make you sigh and say.

"Alright. I'll try it on...but if I'm not convinced, I'm leaving."

There was a zipper in the back of the costume which was already opened. The inside of the suit was soft and even warmer than the outside. You took off your clothing and placed it in a neat pile to the side, but not before making sure the costume vendor wasn't sneaking a peak at you through the badly formed booth. You took one step into the suit and felt the fur of the outfit rub softly against your legs. Your foot eventually hit the hoof below, which felt somewhat like a piece of hard wood. You then but your other leg in and repeated the process.

"Hey. Not bad." you said, looking at yourself through the broken mirror in the booth.

You had to stand on your toes to fill the legs out though which wasn't too difficult. You pulled the costume up to your waist which surprised was quite snug. The tail on the costume hung down from your butt. You giggled as you reached over and played with it some. You looked in the mirror. It was odd but, you could have sworn that this booth was bigger. Sure it wasn't huge to begin with but it seemed just a little smaller now. You shrugged and continued putting on the suit.

It was time to put your arms in the suit next. You decided to do both at the same time. The baggy arms of the costume gave a lot of room for you to maneuver your own arms in. Since Tauren had only three fingers you had to squeeze your index/middle and ring/pinky fingers together to fit them in the slots. But it was strangely comfortable. You looked at your hand and made a fist. It looked just like a tauren's now.

Now for the mask. Taurens had a very hunched over back making it a little odd to fit your head into the suit. You had to crane your neck out to reach the mask. You rested your chin within the suit's snout and you could at last see out of the eye holes. You looked in the mirror to adjust the mouth so it would not look so scrunched up. You almost looked like a real live tauren in the reflection.

"I guess I should zip it up then." You felt down your back for the metal zipper.

As it closed you felt the air in the suit get warmer due to lack of ventilation. With a final "ZIP!", the gaping hole in the suit was all closed up and you could admire the costume in the mirror. You had to admit, the suit was very convincing as you twirled in front of your reflection. You could even see the snout of the mask in front of your face. And the fur made everything so nice and toasty.

"Not bad...I think I'll buy this..." you said as you tugged the hair slightly, which hurt, "Owww...Wait...Why does it hurt?"

You touched the suit's nose. But you could feel it. You pulled the suit's tail but you felt a sharp pain above your butt. When you opened your mouth, the suit did so too. The old gnome was right. The suit WAS magic. You were a tauren female. Panicking, you felt around the back and to your relief felt the metal zipper still there.

"Is everything alright in there? You're being awfully quiet, my girl."

"Uh...Yea...Everything is...just...fine. Wow..."

You exited the booth and saw Zorgo grinning from ear to ear. "I told you it was magic, my girl. Well, what do you think? Do you like it?"

You now towered over the small gnome, everything seemed so much smaller from a tauren's height. Even your body shape had shifted into the form of the tauren suit. You felt strong...powerful...and at peace.

"Y-yes....I think I do...How much did you say it was?"

"Well, tell you what. Since I think that costume suits you so well, I'll let you have it for free. I'll even throw in some tauren sized clothes for you. We can't have you walking around naked can we?"

You blushed and realized that you were standing around exposed. You tried to cover yourself up but Zorgo just laughed.
1122121.title: Donning the tauren suit.

choices: You meet the person in the orc costume there.
11221211.content:
You put on the giant robe Zorgo gave you which fit perfectly. It was also a tad revealing in the front, not that you minded so much. You were much bigger in that area now then you were as a human, so you figured it would be best to show it off. The robe was dark green, making you look like a druid of sorts.

"Very wonderful.", said Zorgo, "I know several young tauren men who would be very interested in meeting you."

You blushed slightly and thanked him for the costume before heading out onto the streets of the Trade District. It was in the middle of the day so it was as bustling as ever. After spending the entirety of your life as a short girl, you marveled as this chance to see what the world was like through a giant tauren's eyes. The local citizens looked up in a mixture of awe and fear at you, you'd think they had never seen a tauren before. You smiled back and continued to the Mage District to show off to your friends before you felt a tap on your back.

"Where the hell do you think you're going, Horde scum?" asked a guard in silver and blue armor.

It didn't occur to you that people would actually think you were a real tauren walking around Stormwind. You reached to the back of your neck to feel for the zipper.

"Oh, s-sorry officer. H-here let me e-explain..." You felt nothing but clumps of fur on your back. The zipper was gone!

"I don't need to hear your damn excuses Horde filth. I lost my family to you monsters and you think you can just walk in the middle of our glorious city without anyone even noticing?! How the hell did you get in here anyway?!"

You tried to think of some sort of excuse to get you out of trouble.

"W-would you believe I-I'm really a human girl a-and this is a c-costume?"

The guard gave a death glare and said. "You're going right to the Stockades with the other trash!"
11221211.title: It's not smart to walk around Stormwind as a Horde

choices: He lets you go if you spy on the Horde for them.
112212112.content:
The dank and smelly darkness of the Stockades was almost unbearable. You wanted to just cry. You skipped a day of class to have some fun and now you were thrown into jail like a common criminal when you hadn't done anything wrong in the first place. You swore that once you got out of here you were going to deep freeze that gnome, Zorgo, and burn his shop down. Approaching foot steps made you look up from your misery.

"You have a visitor Horde maggot." said the guard, "And royalty at that, stand and straight!"

You staggered to your legs, which was easier said than done considering your giant clomps for feet and your chained arms. Standing before you on the other side of the bars was a man dressed in decorated gray armor. A giant scar went across his rugged face. You knew who he was instantly.

"M-my Lord K-King Varian!" You could hardly believe it.

The Lord of Stormwind glared at you. Clearly he was not pleased that a tauren had gotten into his city. But surely he would understand what had happened!

"My men say...that you claim to be human, Horde. Prove it."

"There was a costume shop my lord! And a gnome, he said this costume was magic! But the zipper disappeared...The gnome was named Zorgo! His shop is in the Trade District!"

"My lord." replied one of the guards. "There have been reports from a shop in that area. Very similar to this one's claim."

Good! They had to believe you now! King Varian took the information and rubbed his chin in thought.
112212112.title: Hail to the king, baby.

1122121121.content:
"Excellent. This is just what we've been waiting for," Said Varian. "You will be perfect for spying on the Horde!"

"WHAT?!" You exclaimed."I don't want to go risk my life and spy on the Horde! I want to be normal again and go home!"

The king scowled at you and pressed his face close against the bars. "You'll do it or I'll execute you. It is your duty as a citizen of Stormwind. And if you were truly one of them anyway, you can even consider this a gift of freedom. You will take a boat to the Barrens and you will provide us information on Horde defenses and abilities. Got it?!"

This was the worst day of your life. Ever. You gulped and nodded.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Three days later, you were shipped out to the Barrens from Stormwind with the task to head to Orgrimmar. Every single moment of the trip was pure torture. You would do nothing but complain on the entire boat ride all while adjusting to your new form. This of course what easier said than done on a ship rocking to the waves. When you finally landed, you were given enough supplies to make it to the Crossroads and orders to meet with an agent on top of Razor Hill every week. Of course, where these locations were you could not even begin to imagine. But thankfully they were kind enough to provide you with a map of the entire Horde region.

The ship had landed at a large fortress in the southern Barrens known as Northwatch Hold. The guards provided you with an escort past the local pirates until you reached the main road to the Crossroads. Judging by how desolate the area was, it was going to be a long trip. You sighed, and took your first steps on an epic journey.
1122121121.title: To Orgrimmar.

choices: You come across an odd shaped staff along the way.
11221211211.content:
As you moseyed down the dusty trail you were almost drowning from sweat. Thankfully you had learned how to conjure water and had stored roughly twenty bottles in your pack, but you had already gone through five of them. You stared up at the blazing sun, cursing it's existence.

"Damn tauren...," You muttered to yourself. "Why do they have to have so much fur?!"

You were so annoyed with your situation, that you did not notice a giant raptor lurking behind you. You wiped a handful of sweat from your brow just as the lizard pounced at you. You hard a loud screech and turned around to see the monster on the ground with an arrow impaled through it's chest. Another arrow whizzed through the air and struck the raptor right between the eyes. You squinted your eyes to make out your savior in the distance. A heavily armed white furred female tauren waved at you as she approached.

"Hail friend! Sorry for the scare! Are you alright?"

"Y-yea I think so. T-thanks for saving me."

"Don't mention it! You ought to be more careful though traveling through the Barrens like that."

You laughed nervously, thankful that your first day as an Alliance spy didn't have you end up as dinner for an overgrown lizard.

"My name's Tia Whitehide." She bowed to you. "What's yours?"

You hadn't given a proper name for yourself any thought at all. "Umm, my name is...umm..."

She laughed and patted you on the shoulder. "Oh don't be nervous. Here I'll take you to the Crossroads. We can have a nice meal and talk there."

Well at least you lucked out, your first Horde friend would be leading you right to your first stop before Orgrimmar. You just hoped that nothing would give you away.
11221211211.title: Meeting Tia Whitehide.

112212112111.content:
Despite having practiced walking all on the boat ride, it was still no easy task walking like a normal tauren. Compared to Tia, you were walking like you had been drinking for several hours. She even paused several times and gave you funny looks.

"Are you feeling okay there new friend?"

"Err...Yea. Just the heat. I feel a little woozy."

"Oh, you're not from around here are you? That's natural for your first time here! Just keep your head forward and walk straight ahead. It's as easy as one, two- Oooops!"

You had to stifle your laugh as Tia tripped over her feet and landed face first in the dirt. As she lifted her head up she let out of a hacking cough you noticed a small wooden staff caught between her legs.

"Are you alright?!" You asked.

"Heheh...Yea. I just tripped over this weird wooden pole."

She handed it to you. Most of the staff was withered wood, but there were slight incantations along the base. At the head sat a fearsome bird with its wings outstretched. It was the only piece of the rod that was colored and it glittered gold in the sunlight as you held it up.

"It's a staff...Probably very old by the looks of it." You began to rant about it to Tia. "I'd say it came from the era of the Highborn. Judging by it's condition though it was just dropped here recently, else it would have dried out from the sun and-"

"Um," Tia interrupted with a lost yet curious look. "You see to know an awful lot about artifacts."

You forgot that tauren culture did it's best to avoid magic. You had to think of an excuse. "Oh yes...I spent time with the blood elves in Silvermoon."

"Ahh, that makes sense. What should we do with it?"
112212112111.title: The staff with a bird on it.

1122121121111.content:
"Let's see what it does," You replied. "I mean if it was just left here it can't be any dangerous right?"

"I guess so," Tai clearly was a complete stranger to magic. "What do you think it will do?"

"It's impossible to say without trying it. Probably nothing though. It's ancient."

In your human form, the staff would have gone up to your chest. However, as a giant tauren it was only as tall as your waist. You were even able to hold it in one hand with ease. Absentmindedly, you flicked it in the direction of Tia. A light blue bolt of energy blasted from the mouth of the bird right into her stomach. She gave a loud 'OMPH' and fell backwards right onto her butt, but otherwise seemed unharmed.

"Oh my! Are you alright?!" You asked as you ran over to her.

She giggled. "Yea I'm fine. That was fun!"

"Do you feel okay? There are such things as cursed artifacts, we need to be sure."

Tai began to take it seriously now. She got to feet. "Now that you mention it...A little lighter for some reason. Isn't that odd?"

You noticed something poking out of the stomach area of Tai's metal armor. It was her white fur. It looked almost like she had developed a bit of a pot belly. She noticed your staring, and looked down as well and gasped.

"My belly?!"

Right before your eyes, it slowly began to push its way out of Tia's armor. Leather scarps snapped under the budding pressure. Her entire lower chest-piece fell to the ground with a clunk, exposing a soft furry belly. Tai poked it in disbelief.

"It feels so...soft. And light too!"

She giggled and shook her hips, causing her ballooned tummy to wobble around. How she could handle such a situation so aloofly was beyond you. If your stomach had suddenly blown up you'd be freaking out!

"Tia I don't think you should be fooling around like that. Do you feel any different anywhere else?"

She broke her attention with her stomach and thought. "Hmm, well..."
1122121121111.title: Using the staff.

choices: You visit the local shaman for information on the staff.
Some of the magic seeped out of the staff and onto you!
11221211211111.content:
"No, just in my belly." She gently patted it.

You knew next to nothing about tauren anatomy but it almost looked like she was carrying a baby. Hopefully no one would notice it, even if they got to the Crossroads. At least Tia seemed to be enjoying herself.

"Well, it looks likes all it did was blow up your stomach. I'll look into the staff's power when we get to the Crossroads so we can change you back. Now...which way do we go from here?" You wrapped the staff in a blanket and tucked it into your pack.

"That way," She pointed west. "And I kind of like this. It's so cool! You gotta try this when we get there."

You just rolled your eyes. Never before had you met such a bubbly person in your entire life. You hoped that not all tauren were like this, considering Tia was your first encounter with a real one. If they were all were like her, you'd probably lose your mind in less than a month from the constant excitement.

"By the way. What's your name again? I feel sort of silly traveling like this without even knowing my companions name!"

After finding the staff, you had already forgotten you hadn't even come up with a name for yourself! You tried your best to remember some well known tauren names from books you read. "Um...uh...Sar....Sara. Yea, Sara Runetotem. That's it."

You thanked the light that you had found such a gullible companion. "Ah, well it's a pleasure to be traveling with you Sara!"

----------------------------------------------------------

The trip to the Crossroads took another hour. When you finally arrived, you felt both relieved and frightened beyond belief. It was a literal crossroads of all manner of Horde. Each and everyone of them probably had the power to rip your spine out and floss their teeth with it. Orcs, trolls, and even other tauren all gave glares to you and your partner as you went towards the inn. Thankfully, none of them had yet noticed Tia's girth.

"Isn't this place the greatest!"

"Y-yea...very cheery."

The two of you went towards the tallest building in the camp, where you rented two beds for the night. Even though it was a mere hole in the wall with linen bedsheets, it was a pleasant sight compared to the desert and the rough seas you had endured for the past few days. You went to sleep instantly without even taking off your traveling equipment. The next day...
11221211211111.title: No. (Just the belly inflates).

choices: You both continue to meet the shaman at the beach.
112212112111111.content:
It was a rainy day, the following morning and it neatly mirrored your mood. Despite having slept till nearly noon, you were cranky beyond all belief. You were so used to the wonderfully comfy beds at the mage quarters that sleeping on hard rock with raggedly sheets made you feel like a trogg. Looking around for Tia, you spotted her conversing with several Horde members. She still had her giant gut yet she gleefully chatted away with a female orc and male troll, both of whom looked completely bored.

She noticed you approach. "Oh Sara! Hi! Guys this is my new friend, Sara Runetotem."

The troll grunted a hello, the orc was a bit more chatty though. "You seem rather weak for a warrior."

"Um, I'm a spellcaster...like a druid." You answered shyly.

The orc didn't seem too impressed though. "No offense to you, but those who casts spells tend to be cowards. To fight at close range. To see the whites of your enemies eyes...That is true honor. I hate mages."

"Sure...Uh, Tia we need to get going. We need to see the- uh- shaman."

"Oh sure Sara. Bye guys!"

You had to practically drag her away from the table. The troll and the orc seemed rather glad you came to take Tia away, and they began to talk to each other. You walked outside with Tia and made sure you were out of earshot.

"So," Tia finally asked. "Why do we need to see the shaman?"

"You idiot. I just made that up. What in the world are you doing talking to people like that?!" You pointed to her stomach. "What if we get caught?!"

She giggled. "Oh come on. I think it's cool. Besides no one noticed..."

She patted herself on the tummy. You sighed. "Look, maybe we should see the head shaman. I can't make heads or tails about this staff. Who would that shaman be? I've never been here before."

"Oh, that would be Sergra! Everyone thinks she's mean, but she's usually nice to me though. Come on I'll introduce you to her!"

She grabbed you by the hand before you could react and dragged you through the rain. She was taking you to a large watch tower on the hill in the camp. Up the rickety ramps she carried you until she almost threw you in the face of a stern looking orc woman inside the hut at the top.

The orc was busy cleaning a massive battle axe with oil. "Who are you?" She growled with a hint of anger in her voice.

Tia leaned into the small room with a grin. "Heya Sergra! This is my new friend Sara!"

"Tia? Hmm, you've...grown..."

"Yea, we actually came to talk to you about that! I saved Sara from some raptor and then we found this weird stick and-"

You butted in. "M-maybe I should explain. H-how do you do Miss?"

You reached your hand out but Sergra returned your greeting with a glare. "Please make it quick. I do not have all day ladies."

"U-um y-yes...W-well we were headed through the Barrens and Tia h-happened to trip over this s-staff, see?"

You held out the rod and unwrapped it from the blanket. Sergra's angry eyes shifted to that of a surprised look. Gently, she grabbed it out of your hands. She lifted it up and examined it.

"P-please be careful with that," You said. "I was fooling around with it last time and Tia ended up like that." You pointed to her stomach.

"Relax. I've seen this before."

"Y-you have? Where!? Is there a way to return Tia to normal again?!"

"But Sara, I like being like this..."

"Quiet both of you." Sergra stood up and went outside. She pointed to the coast in the far East. "Out on the Barren's coast is a fellow shaman encamped who studies water. She made the cure for when this staff had made an appearance in the Crossroads the last time."

"The last time?" You asked.

"Yes, a shifty blood elf character came through here a month ago and caused havoc with that staff. It took four squadrons of guards just to remove him from the encampment. Most of his victims ended up worse than Tia here. Why he would drop his main weapon of chaos is beyond me. It matters not though. I'll trust this with you, but do not test me. If you decide to pull a few pranks like he did...your hide will be my new cloak."

You gulped. "Y-yes, understood."

"You can head to the shore on some of the remaining kodos we have stabled here. Just mention to the keeper that I sent you."

"Alright! More traveling! I'll meet you there Sara!" Tia jumped off the tower and landed gracefully in the mud below.

"Where does she get the energy..." You muttered under your breathe.

You turned to leave but Sergra grabbed you by the robe. "Why are you traveling with Tia?"

"Huh? I don't know. I met her in the desert and she helped me out, I guess. Plus I need to make things right considering I used the staff on her and all..."

"You don't judge her because of the way she is?"

You were confused. "What do you mean?"

Sergra sighed. "Listen, I knew Tia since she was a toddler. She had two wonderful parents, whom I was good friends with, and a house not far from here. But it didn't last. Her parents were killed when the Alliance raided from the north. She was left alone for all those years, not a single friend at all."

You couldn't help but feel guilty that she was orphaned by Alliance. "You never once thought that she was a little odd? The way she acts so aloof and happy go lucky?" Asked Sergra.

"W-well I thought she acted a little strange at first but she's been nice...so I don't mind..."

For the first time since you were introduced to her, Sergra grinned. "She's like a little sister to me. I was really frightened there for a moment when she came in here with that giant stomach. I thought she was pregnant...Please, promise you'll watch over her on this trip for me. We can call it even for the free kodo."

You smiled back and nodded. Sergra shooed you away after that, and you went to meet Tia at the stables.
112212112111111.title: The shaman's wisdom.

choices: You don't make it before nightfall.
1122121121111111.content:
Tia seemed even more excited when you were given the mounts you would be riding. You had never actually seen a real live kodo before. Though you wished they had warned you in class how badly they stunk. Your gray kodo smelt like it had been rifling through the garbage. Tia gave her brown skinned one a big hug.

"Aren't they great?!"

"Not exactly the word I would use. They certainly look...sturdy though."

The kodo handler helped both of you onto the beasts. Tia had some difficult because of her stomach, but eventually she sat comfortably in the saddle.

"Okay ladies," Said the keeper. "Hang on tight. If you let go, there's a good chance it will be the last thing you ever do."

Before you could ask why, he smacked your kodo on the rump and it took off like a bullet. You nearly fell off from the speed of the monster. Tia's kodo was not far behind you. While you screamed in dumbfounded terror, Tia was laughing like a maniac. The two kodo ran down the road, kicking up clouds of dust thick enough to gag anyone passing through them.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -

On a nearby hill, just outside of the Crossroads stood a cloaked figure. From under his hood pointed ears jutted out on his head. Because of the rain and darkness, most of his features were shadowed save for giant white grin stretched across his face. He watched the clouds of dust created by your kodo disappear in the distance.

"What an interesting pair...I can't wait to thank them for recovering my staff..."

He turned around to a giant purple bird with a saddle on it's back. He hopped comfortably into it, and charged down the hill down towards the trail you were on.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -

You had finally stopped screaming. Partially it was because you were getting used to the speed of the kodo. But mostly because even opening your mouth a crack would cause a mouthful of sand to take up residence in your gaping piehole. Tia was still laughing like crazy, probably used to riding on kodo. Meanwhile you felt like you were going to be sick. Your kodo passed by hills of sand and trees like they were nothing. Between the blinding rain and ripping wind, you could not open the map and make sure you were heading in the right direction.

"Tia! How are we supposed to know we're going to the right place!?"

"We're here already!" She yelled back.

There was a sudden stop and you went flying off your kodo. You braced yourself to hit hard dirt ground but instead landed in salty water. Gasping for air, you swam to the surface. Tia laughed, but gave you a hand to pull you to the shore. The kodo had stopped at a jutting piece of land at the edge of the sea. There was a large tent flaying in the winds near the shoreline. A warm glow resonated from within. Someone was home at least.

Tia threw a towel over your shoulders. "This is the Tidus Stair! Come on, let's go met the shaman."

You were soaked from horn to hoof, so you were of course looking forward to a warm fireplace. Inside the tent were two other tauren women, each dressed in bones and leather straps. They seemed primitive in every sense of the word. Expecting a cold greeting, you were surprised when they smiled at you and instead offered a warm welcome.

"Greetings fellow tauren sisters. What brings you to our camp?"

You introduced yourselves and explained your situation. When showing them the staff you had found, they fondled it curiously before handing it back to you. The two women were called Mahren Skyseer and Islen Waterseer and were shaman that were very interested in it's properties.

"So," Spoke Islen. "You need me to give you the cure for Tia's growth?"

"Yes please, if it's not any trouble."

"No, not at all. In fact you may call it a reward for finding that trouble-making elf's staff. Just a moment, I'll go speak to the water spirits to get you the potion."

Islen got up and went outside to the sea. You took a sip of the herbal tea they had offered you.

"I'd be cautious from now on, both of you." Spoke the other tauren, Mahren.

"Why? Do you think he's a dangerous man?"

"He had the battle hardened troops of the Crossroads in an uproar for an entire week with the mischief he created. He may only be a prankster, but he could be very powerful if he created something like this. All I'll say is if you ever encounter him in your travels, don't try to fight him. Just run."

"Oh, we'll be fine! Right Sara!?"

You gave a weak yes. The last thing you needed on this dangerous spying assignment was an even more dangerous convict chasing you. Eventually Islen returned with several vials of blue liquid. She offered one to Tia and told her to only take a sip.

"Do I have to Sara...?"

"Tia, we are not going to Orgrimmar with you like that. Now come on. We need to get to Razor Hill before nightfall."

She groaned and took a small sip. Instantly, her belly began to rumble and shrink like it was losing air. In a matter of seconds Tia was back to normal, much to her disapproval. She sighed and poked her stomach where it had been a giant balloon just moments ago. You thanked the shaman for the cure and packed the potions next to the staff.

"So Tia," You said, stepping out into the rain. "Where do we go for Razor Hill from here?"

"It's just north of here and across the river!" She hopped on her kodo. "Come on! Let's go."
1122121121111111.title: The cure and the shadow.

choices: You wake up and the elf is talking to Tia.
You wake up alone in a prison.
11221211211111111.content:
It was already very late in the day thanks to the fact that you slept through most of it. By the time you both crossed the bridge into Durotar, it was past dinner time and a symphony of stomach growls muted the stomping of the kodo. You grabbed the reins of your riding beast and pulled hard to make it stop. Thankfully it obeyed your command, and Tia stopped her mount as well.

"There's no way we're going to get to Razor Hill tonight Tia. Let's set up camp here."

You had brought tents and campfire equipment, in no time a well made camp was created on the side of the road. You collapsed on the ground as your stomach rumbled. Food had not been in your belly since the you left the boat to the Barrens. You hadn't eaten in days. Tia seemed to also be hungry as she looked down at you.

"I'm starving, want to get some food?"

"You brought food??" You asked hopefully.

"Of course! What did you think we've been riding on this whole time?" She pointed to her kodo.

She couldn't be serious. "Eat our mounts? Didn't say it was cute mere hours ago?!"

"Yea, but we're hungry now. And I don't think we can catch anything edible at this time of night." She grinned and held up an axe.

------------------------------------------------------------------

Moments later you found yourself chewing on the giant leg bone of Tia's former mount. While you were content with just one leg, Tia had scarfed down the rest of the kodo before you could even finish it. She was already nearly asleep, patting her belly happily. Kodo tasted a lot like cow, only more rich. Still you couldn't help but feel that it was wrong to eat her mount. It was like eating someone's pet cat.

"I don't think I can finish..."

"Really?! I'll have it if you don't want it."

"How can you possibly eat that much? You're going to make yourself sick."

She giggled. "You wouldn't last a week in the Barrens. I can tell that much. You need to be prepared to do whatever it takes to survive including-"

For the first time since you had met Tia, she had a serious look on her face. She stared behind you and looked like a dog would when it sensed someone coming in the distance. You turned around and caught a glimpse of a figure walking towards you in the darkness. When he finally came into light you nearly gasped. It was a blood elf, he had glowing green eyes and long yellow hair. There was a distinct blond goatee on his chin just below a massive grin.

"Good evening ladies," He spoke. "I believe you have something of mine."

Acting quickly, you cast the first spell that came to your mind. "FIREBLAST!" A bolt of fire launched at the elf's face. However, he was able to put his hand up to block it saving his face from the attack but badly burning his hand. Tia had already grabbed her bow and arrow, and fired a shot right at him. With a simple wave of his injured hand, the wooden arrow burst into flames before it even reached him.

"Now ladies, let's not get violent-"

"Frost Nova!" You yelled. A chilling wave of ice launched forward at the grinning elf, wrapping itself around his legs and preventing him from moving. You began to call forth more flames and aimed right for where he would be standing. "Flamestrike!" Cracks of red hot fire formed beneath the ground of ice. The grin on the elf's face finally disappeared when bursts of flame magic seeped out from the frost and swarmed around him. You were nearly out of mana at this point, so you prayed that it would be enough to stop him. Your heart sank when the flames cleared and the elf stood encased in a giant block of ice. He then let loose a giant wave of magic which allowed him to break free from your frost spell. You had to escape. There was only one thing that you had left...

"Tia! Run! Polym-" You began to yell.

"Arcane Blast!" He pointed at you and fired a bolt of purple energy right at your face. That was the last thing you remembered before hitting the ground.
11221211211111111.title: Meeting the elf.

choices: The orc from the inn at the Crossroads!
112212112111111111.content:
The last time you had felt like this was when you downed five pints of Thunderbrew as part of a bet. Your head was throbbing as you struggled to remember what had happened. You were inside your tent, it was still dark out but at least the rain had stopped. The sound of a suave male voice coming from outside your tent immediately made you jump up, as you recalled your fight with the blood elf before becoming unconscious. You torn open the tent flap and saw Tia conversing which the elf. She was shaking his hand.

"I'm Tia Whitehide!"

"Pleased to meet you, my name is Joric Brightsky."

Apparently you had slept through something. "Tia! What the hell is going on here?!"

"Oh, hey Sara! This is Joric. Joric, this is Sara Runetotem, the friend traveling with me."

"Tia I don't care about that! He attacked us! Why are you even talking to him!?"

Joric cleared his throat. "Forgive me for interrupting my tauren friend, but it was you that cast the first spell when I calmly approached you. I only struck back in self defense. Speaking of which, how's your head? I tried to hold back as best as I could so I wouldn't harm you."

You felt around your forehead and grabbed a linen bandage. Had he put that on? "Um..yea...I feel better."

"Good. You took me by surprise there. I would not have expected a tauren to know anything about mage spells." He showed his left hand, which was burned and covered in a heavy bandage.

"See Tia? He's a nice person." Which was true, you supposed. If he was really dangerous, you both would have probably been dead by now. He sat down next to the glowing campfire and sighed.

"Now that introductions are out of the way. Would you be so kind as to return my latest piece of artwork?" He motioned to your backpack.

Your pack opened by itself. Out flew the staff wrapped in the blanket. It unraveled itself and gently landed it your hands. You decided to ask a few questions before handing it over. "Artwork? You call this cursed item art!? And why should I return it to you!? You were the one who caused havoc in the Crossroads for days right? Who's to say you won't do it again if I return it to you?"

"No one ever understands my art...," He muttered. "Listen, it has been a passion of mine to create ways to make people...bigger. I suppose you can call it perverse, most do, but I enjoy doing it. That staff was the newest and greatest method for doing so I had ever invented."

He stared into your eyes with his soft emerald ones. "What happened at the Crossroads was an accident. I was just experimenting with the staff and it went completely out of control. I was lucky to escape from there with my life as a matter of fact...Look, all I'm asking is you give me the staff and we go our separate ways. That's all."

"But why should we hand this over? I still don't trust you. We can just report you to the authorities." You glared at the elf.

He merely chuckled. "Because if you do...Perhaps I might let slip a few details concerning your own identities. You wouldn't like that, would you? Sarah..."

You gulped. Impossible! There was no way he could have known about you really being a human! Tia gave you a concerned look and asked. "What does he mean Sara?"

The elf laughed again and said. "Oh it's nothing you should worry about Tia, now come. You're heading to Orgrimmar yes? I can show you a quicker route as payment for-"

A steel tipped arrow pierced right through Joric's right shoulder. He gasped in pain and fell to the ground. The shooter was...
112212112111111111.title: Allow me to introduce myself...

1122121121111111111.content:
A female orc calmly walked over to the fallen elf, another arrow was strung and aimed right for his head. Something about her seemed familiar to you...She was the orc girl that Tia was talking to at the inn at the Crossroads! She came in striking distance of Jaric and the pulled out two large axes.

"Hello again Tia, I'm glad I decided to follow you two. I thought something was suspicious about that swollen stomach of hers."

Tia was completely confused. "You!? But wait! I know what Joric did was bad, but he didn't mean to do it right Joric? It was an accident!"

The orc scuffed. "I don't care about what happened at the Crossroads." She kicked Joric in the ribs. "All I care about is getting revenge for my sister."

She swing her axe down at his head, but he quickly but up a barrier of mana. You knew how draining such a spell was, it would not last long even if he was a skilled mage. Joric used the same spell he did on you and set the orc woman flying back. However, she was able to stand right back up. Giving a fearsome battle cry, she charged right at him. Joric turned to you and yelled.

"The staff! Give me the staff!"

You had little time to think about it and quickly tossed him the wooden rod. He caught it and firmly aimed it at the orc warrior. The same light blue blast shot from the bird's mouth, only this time it was much stronger and lasted longer. Once again, the orc was throw back. She landed in the dust and slowly got up before realizing what was about to happen to her. She reached out at Joric.

"No...You bastard!"

She was cut off though, as she grasped her metal tunic in pain. You correctly guessed that her stomach was growing underneath her armor. That wasn't all though. Everywhere was growing on her. You watched with interest as her reasonably sized bosom began to inch forward in cup size. Her hips swelled outward slightly, making her equipment look unbearably tight on her. This of course restricted her movements and she couldn't run over to have Joric stop the process. It looked like someone had given her armor several sizes too small. Tia took this time to help Joric to his feet.

"Joric...Did you really do that to her sister?" She asked.

Joric stared coldly at the ground. "I needed someone to test it on. She volunteered..."

Every second filled the orc up with a massive amount of air. Her clothes groaned under the stress and pressure. You also noticed that she had become considerably taller. Spots of green skin were visible through the cracks of the ripping armor. It looked like she was hiding a kodo in her shirt. Her toes now poked out from her chain boots. She had long given up trying to attack Joric and was busy prying open her extremely tight armor. Eventually she succeeded and her contained body swelled outwards with a flop.

"H-how big will she get?" You asked Joric.

He dusted himself off and admired his handy work. "Just enough so she'll float away and won't be a bother to us anymore."

Her fingers now resembled overcooked sausages and her cheeks puffed with air. "Will she be okay like this? I mean she could be floating for days!"

Joric chuckled as the orc girl tried desperately to cover her exposed self. "She could indeed. But the landing is completely safe. And the air provides you with all the nutrients you'll need while in the sky. You'll just be starving when you land."

"That explains Tia eating an entire kodo..." You thought to yourself. The orc's head was inflated as well as the rest of her body. She towered over the three of you like a blimp. However, she still maintained a distinct feminine shape. She had curves beyond belief, but she just looked like an overinflated orc balloon. Even a balloony shine radiated on her skin. There was a change of expression in the girl's face from anger to fear, she looked down at her ballooned toes. You wonder what was wrong, but then you noticed that her feet were several inches off the ground. The twenty foot tall orc balloon was beginning to float away.

"I'll get you for this!" Cried the angry girl, though the threat was somewhat dismissed by her squeaky voice. "This is why I hate mages! When I get back you're dead at first sight! You hear me?!"

"I'm sure you will." Laughed Joric.

The orc was rising faster now, floating over the heads of you. She sailed away into the night sky, stomach first, uttering every curse word imaginable at the laughing elf. Soon she was a green speck in the starry overhead. Joric clapped his hands together.

"Well that's that. To Orgrimmar, right ladies?"

Unfortunately, Joric was greeted by replies from both of you at once. "Why did you do that to her?!-That was cool Joric!-I don't trust you with that staff!-Can you do that to me?!-Something like that should be illegal!-Please?! Pretty please!?"

He covered his ears. "Ladies, ladies...please one at a time."

"Listen elf!" You jabbed a finger in his face. "You even point that thing at me and I'm breaking it in half!"

"Fair enough. Tia, how about you?"

"It looked like a blast! Can you please try that on me!?"

"Of course." He smirked. "At least someone appreciates my art. But let's not discuss this now Tia. Let's focus at the task on hand. You ladies both have a mount, correct?"

You nodded, but Tia's stomach growled. "We kinda...Had to eat mine..." She laughed nervously.

He frowned. "Well that's no good. We'd be able to make it to Orgrimmar before daybreak if we ride...But now it might take much longer...And neither of you can fit on my bird. Hmmm."

He began pacing the ground in thought, staff still in hand. Looking down at it, a grin suddenly grew across his face.

"Good news Tia. You may get to try the staff out much sooner than I thought..."

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----

The sun was slowly peaking over the horizon as a purple hawkstrider and a gray kodo carrying you and Joric jumped from rock to rock. There was a long rope tied to your kodo's harness which trailed all the way up to the sky, like you were carrying a balloon. Joric looked back at you and grinned.

"You feeling okay there cow-girl?"

"This is so wrong on so many levels..."

"Oh lighten up. Just be thankful it doesn't take two days to get there. Besides, Tia seems to be enjoying herself."

You rolled your eyes and looked up in the sky. The rope led to a huge blimp-like white furred tauren girl, and tied itself around her tail. Tia was at a much bigger size than the orc girl, and flew through the air like bird. A giant balloon bird. Like the orc, she still had a feminine shape but was just huge all over. She had her arms outstretched and was laughing uncontrollably.

She looked between her giant breasts and called down to you. "Hey Sara! You gotta try this!"
1122121121111111111.title: Inflating the orc woman.

11221211211111111111.content:
Joric's company was a more pleasurable than Tia's in some ways. He was a bit creepy when discussing his 'art', but at the same time he wasn't thrill crazy like Tia. Nevertheless, you tried to keep the topics of conversations on magic and spells, which he shared a deep interest in.

"Yes, I was quite surprised to see a tauren of all things casting mage spells! But then of course, you aren't really a tauren are you?"

You were thankful that Tia was high enough so that she wouldn't hear this. "How do you know me? The real me?"

Joric just grinned. "I have my ways. Don't worry though, I have no interest in serving the Horde. Nor do I have any interest in ratting you out."

At least he provided you with a small comfort. It felt good getting that secret off your chest. Even if the person you were revealing it too was an elf who had odd tastes. Joric pointed ahead of you.

"Take a look. Orgrimmar, the orc warrior city."

Under the rising run was a large orange canyon. At the entrance stood a formidable wall of white solid rock, complete with logs as support and giant watchtowers on both sides. The only door was a small opening at the base of the wall. Even in distance, the metal of the gates and chains gleamed. You heard the sounds of a loud horn, followed by gruff shouting coming from over the canyon. Inside lay the largest population of Horde in all Azeroth. The thought of entering such a place gave you shivers. Still, you couldn't help but be impressed by the magnificence of its appearance. Tia probably had the best view out of the three of you.

"Hey!" She called out from above. "I can see Orgrimmar from here!"

"Hang on Tia! We're going to get you down now! Joric, there's a spell to undo this. Right?"

He nodded. "Certainly, one moment. Let me get the reagents for it." He reached into his pack. Suddenly, his face went pale. "Uh oh..."

"What uh oh?"

He rubbed the back of his head and laughed slightly. "It seems...I am out of Blowrock dust...."

"And? Is that bad?" You asked with ever growing concern.

"Well...Without it we'd have to wait for Tia to lose air. That could take weeks. I can't undo the spell without it. "

You couldn't believe what you were hearing. "Weeks?! W-what about the potions we got from those shaman! Won't those work?!"

"Yes they would...But you sort of crushed them when I knocked you out during our fight."

It took every ounce of your mage training to not panic, and not punch Joric in the face. "Okay...okay....And where would we GET Blowrock dust?"

"Well...I usually purchase it from a vendor in Orgrimmar. However, he's left for Thunderbluff the entire week." He started to laugh nervously.

"Can't we just poke a hole in her or something?!"

"Don't be ridiculous. She'd explode and then where would we be?"

"Do you have any BETTER suggestions?!"

"In fact I do. There is a large quantity of the stuff underneath Orgrimmar itself, within an underground cave called Ragefire Chasm. Of course, the cave is now a lair for a bunch of cultists. Meaning acquiring the dust will be slightly...difficult..."

Looking up at Tia, who was freely floating in and the air and completely unaware of the situation, you sighed. How did you always get into these situations?
11221211211111111111.title: Orgrimmar, and the new task.

112212112111111111111.content:
There was a part of you, a very large part of you, that wanted nothing more then to complete this Horde spying task, go home, and then find a way to return to normal. But Tia had helped you a lot already on this journey. You knew you would not be here right now if she hadn't found you. Chances are, you'd probably be dead.

"Alright...We'll do it. Only for Tia's sake though! You need to promise to never use that thing again unless you have a sure fire way to get here back to normal! Got it!?" You jabbed at the elf's nose.

"Understood. I'll let our floating friend know the plan then."

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----

Despite being early in the morning, Orgrimmar was bustling with activity. You had never seen such a sight before. Hunters proudly hung their freshly caught prey to sell for food. Loud auctions were heard on the street from the nearby auction house. There were even Horde sitting on the roofs of buildings, communing with each other and taking in the morning air. Every building was decorated with lovely spikes and barbs. The whole city looked like it was ready for war. Crowds of heavily armed orcs and trolls stomped passed you as Joric motioned you to keep up.

"Stay close to me. This is an even rougher place than the Crossroads."

He didn't have to tell you twice, for at that very moment a badly beaten tauren male was tossed out of a nearby bar. He pleaded with you to help him but you ignored him and stepped over his bruised body. Much to your relief, Joric was leading you to a sect in the canyon covered with giant drapes from above. This provided some well needed shade from the sun, but you didn't dare stop to rest. Foul looking humanoid creatures lingered in the shadows of buildings, eying you as you passed by. They were undead, part of the Forsaken that joined the Horde after the Third War.

Joric led you down the row of shadowy buildings and into the very center of the city. It was a large crevice filled with tents. A strange purple light shone from the braziers littered around the hole. At the edge of the canyon was a large cave entrance. Inside you spotted cracks of lava, a sweltering wave of heat rushed at you. It was safe to say this was the entrance.

Joric smiled as he wiped his brow. "Well this is it. Be on your guard. There's no telling what we'll find in there."
112212112111111111111.title: To Ragefire.

1122122.content:
"Do you have anything else? I don't really like Tauren." you said.

"Understood! Understood!" Zorgo dug into a pile of costumes on his counter. "How about this one my dear?"

He held up a pale skinned suit with fiery red hair in braids. It looked like it was meant for a child by the size of it.

"Err...what is it?" you asked.

"This here is a dwarf costume. It's a pretty unusual costume, wouldn't you say?"

"I guess...But how am I supposed to fit into it? The Tauren one I could pull off maybe but this looks way too tight."

"Not too worry...The suit is flexible, see?" he stretched the suit vertically to almost twice it's height. "So are you interested?"
1122122.title: A dwarf costume?

11221221.content:
After giving it some thought, you eventually decide such a costume was as good as any. Better you go around looking like a pale red head than a giant walking cow. You kindly thanked the old gnome and paid him for the suit before heading back to your room at the University. It would be awhile before classes would end, so it was just you alone in an empty room with an odd costume. You were completely bored at this point so you picked up the costume to try it on.

"Might as well...," You said to yourself. "I mean, who's going to know right?"

You took off your robes and tossed them aside. The dwarf suit was just as stretchy as when Zorgo gave it to you. Of course there was no zipper on it so you had to enter through the mouth, which felt a little like you were being eaten by the costume. The suit stretched to your own proportions, you looked in the mirror and saw a comically tall dwarf staring right back at you.

"Well I got to hand it to Zorgo," You muttered. "He makes a pretty damn convincing outfit."

Something in you felt weird though. A tingling of sorts that spread throughout your body. You felt off balance as you reached out to your bed to support yourself, grabbing it much sooner than you would normally have. You looked around and noticed that everything was steadily growing around you. At first you thought that you might have accidentally casted some sort of spell but you were instantly proved wrong when you felt your body begin to reshape itself.

As you decreased in height, every part of your body began to shrink with it except your thighs and breasts. It occurred to you what was going on.

"I'm becomin' a dwarf!" You yelled in a distinct dwarfish lass accent.

There was something else happening too. You felt like you were drifting into a deep sleep and you could hardly keep your eyes open. Something was attacking your sub conscious, and you felt a sort of second presence inside of you. You were beginning to black out as you stopped at an average dwarf lady's height. Everything went completely dark...

---------------------------------------------------------------------

The dwarf that was once you stood naked in the middle of the room grinning.

"Sorry to do this to you lass," Spoke your form. "But it's your body or no body."

There was a _______ spirit inside the costume.
11221221.title: Dwarf suit activate.

112212211.content:
You couldn't believe what had just happened. Somehow the costume had transformed you into a dwarf and now you couldn't even move your own body. You could, however, still see what was going on and whatever it was in control was looking at your dwarf shaped hands.

"What are you?!" You tried to scream, but your mouth did not move.

Strangely enough, whatever was in control of your body seemed to hear you as it paused and said.

"What's this? You're still here lass?"

"Of course I'm still here! This is my body!"

"Not anymore I'm afraid."

A cold shiver ran down your spine. Whatever this was had possessed your body! You might be stuck like this forever!

"C-can you tell me what you are at least? A demon?" You asked with a tremble in your voice.

"Name's Helga Thundermace. I am...well was...a real dwarf woman once."

A warmth of relief came over you as you were thankful a demon wasn't inhabiting your body. "What happened then? Why did you possess me when I wore the costume?"

"Well...Lemme begin about one hundred years ago. I was a proud dwarf warrior traveling the Eastern Kingdoms in search of adventure. It just so happens that during my travels I came across a wee gnome magician. He claimed to have discovered a map leading to lost treasures in some nearby ruins so being foolishly greedy I decided to help him in his quest. Sure enough, there was treasure in those old ruins. But the cur double crossed me and cast a curse on me, changing me into a wearable costume."

The gears in your head were being to turn. "You mean...that Zorgo guy was-!"

Sarah blushed slightly while Cordell tried to stop his explosive nosebleed. "Y-yes, let's get on with it."

And with that, Gretta lead Sarah into Gretta's work area. There was the smell of sot and iron lingering in the air, many books and scrolls lay all over the tables. Gretta cleared off the largest table and placed down the tattoo book.

"Strip down, lass."

Sarah hesitated but quietly obeyed. It was somewhat of a relief to break free of the much too tight robes as she fidgeted around the room in her small undergarments before laying down stomach up on the bench.

"That's it, this won't take long at all."

Sarah yelped slightly as a tingly feeling pricked her in her chest, just along her massive cleavage. The stingy hot sensation faded into an ice cold touch again. The dwarf woman seemed to be taking her time with this one. After what seemed like forever, Gretta put her needle down.

"All done." She smirked. "Enjoy it."

Sarah jumped to her feet and looked down at her chest. The design was a very peculiar shape. It was blood red and looked somewhat like a woman, only much more squatter and condensed.

"You sure this is the right one?"

"Absolutely, the effects should start any moment now."

Sure enough, before Sarah could reply back a tingling feeling went down her spine. She began to look herself over to spot any changes occurring. Little did she know, her tramp stamp from behind was slowly fading into her skin, an added effect that Gretta decided to include with her plan.

"What's going on?" Asked Sarah with a sense of rising concern.

"Oh, just what you brought upon yourself, lass."

Sarah angrily turned to face the dwarf when she suddenly noticed that she wasn't looking down at Gretta as much as she had been a few seconds ago. That's when it hit her. She was shrinking.

"What did you do to me, you freaking midget!?"

Gretta just replied with a hearty laugh. Sarah's world was growing larger around her, she felt like she was getting crushed by an unseen hand from above her. Oddly enough her figure wasn't shrinking with her, it was staying the same size giving her an almost stout appearance just like the woman on the tattoo. Her body fat plumped up all the right areas, including her stomach. Sarah suddenly realized what was happening to her.

"Yer making me into a dwarf, you bitch!" She shouted in a hoarse accent, much to her surprise.

Gretta continued to laugh as the girl neared her own height. "Well done, they do train mages well don't they? Anyway call this a price for yer vanity 'human'. Good night."

Before Sarah could react, Gretta reached into her pocket and threw a handful of dust in her face. Sarah coughed slightly and felt herself become increasingly drowsy as she desperately tried to make a grab for Gretta. She blacked out just before she came in reach.

She woke up...

"No."

Sarah looked herself over in the mirror.

"No, no, no!"

She was short, and fat, and short!! (as if she hadn't been short enough before!) and the absolute worst thing was that that treacherous dwarven bitch hadn't even fixed her nose.

"No!"

"It's me, Sarah! Don't come in!"

It was so long that the ends dragged on the ground, and the belt barely fit around her new, thicker waist. For the first time in her life, she had to decide whether to knot it over or under a healthy gut, and finally decided on over, where her large bust help keep it in place. At least she still had that, even if it was now much more proportionate to the rest of her.

When she was satisfied that her robes weren't going to fly open, she flung the door open and fixed James with a stare. "You! Your assistant did this to me!"

James gasped. "Sarah? Why on Azeroth did you ask for--?"

"I didn't!" she wailed. "All I wanted was a nicer nose. Now look at me!"

"I think your nose looks lovely. And, er, well, if you're not satisfied, I suppose this one can be on the house--"

"I don't want it on the house!" Sarah snapped. "I want it reversed! Undone! I want to be able to see my toes again! Got it?"

"It's not that early," James said, wringing his hands apologetically. "Gretta's the only one who knows how, and--"

122.content:
Samantha Stonegully was amazingly pleased with how things were going.

The dwarven rogue had spent years trying to achieve that one big score. Years of pickpocketing dirty magazines and chew toys, of opening lockboxes only to find a few coppers and some old leaves, of sneaking through crumbling catacombs, wading through vile swamps, and searing her fair skin to a crisp under the desert sun. All in pursuit of this.

At last, she'd found it. A treasure trove for the ages -- enough to keep her in luxury for a lifetime. Her vault in the Ironforge bank overflowed with it. Gold coins stacked to the ceiling. Bushels of sparkling jewels. Bolts of priceless cloth. She'd almost gotten it semi-sort-of-legally, even.

Hefting one of the ruby-filled urns into the vault, she caught a glimpse of herself in the polished golden surface. She looked good. Flame-red hair tied back in a braid, eyes the color of honey, and a fantastic build. While other dwarves stuffed themselves with sausage and guzzled down mug after mug of beer, she'd abstained, keeping herself slender and stealthy. Oh, she was still curvy -- that was a given for dwarfs -- but the black leather of her working clothes hugged trim, toned curves rather than the doughy rolls so many of her sisters and brothers sported.

Although now that I've got enough money to retire, she reflected, I suppose I don't have to be so careful. Finally, she could let loose and eat whatever she wanted.

On the other hand, perhaps it wasn't time to relax just yet. She'd made a lot of enemies in her day. Perhaps it was time to visit a local mage, someone who could help disguise her distinctive looks, so she could enjoy her 'retirement' in peace. Hmm...

After a moment, Sam grinned. She'd made up her mind.

1222.content:
"Chug, chug, chug, chug -- yeah! Thas' tha spirit, lass!" The Thunderbrew server cheered as Sam slammed her empty mug down on the counter next to a dozen others.

Sam smirked. "Nothin' to it." Maybe I don't drink much, she thought, but I can still hold it when I do!

She'd thrown herself into the celebration, even purchasing an official Brewfest dress from the vendor. And she'd committed herself to trying everything the celebration had to offer. She'd already packed away so many helpings of pretzals, cheese, and sausage that she felt a little like a stuffed meat dumpling. Which she'd also been eating plenty of.

Thank th' gods for these loose skirts, she thought fervently, smoothing them over the taut bulge of her stomach. To the server, she chimed, "Hit me again!"

"You got it, lass," the server said, pouring out another drink. Sam tossed it back in one thirsty gulp.

"Well, if it isn't Slicer Sam," said a voice from behind her. "Never see you here, do I?"

She turned around. "Hello, Mike."

Two-Bits Mike, an old human partner of hers from her days in the Dwarven District of Stormwind, stood there with a wicked half-smile on his face. "What's the game, Slicer? I've been watchin' you eat your way from one end of the grounds to the other. When you go off your diet, you don't do it by halves, do ya?"

"I don't do anything by halves."

"Not even 'eat a cheese wheel'," Mike nodded. "I've noticed. Careful, Slicer, hard to pull jobs when you can't fit through the window."

"Haven't ya heard?" Sam said. "I'm out of the game. Scored big. I'll leave the petty burglaries to you."

"Retired, hmm?" He looked her over. "Fattenin' yourself up for civilian life, then, are you? Can't say as how I mind; if I'm rememberin' our little roll in the hay right, you've got a woeful lack of the usual dwarven cushionin'."

Sam popped another dumpling in her mouth. "Wmmph, ymmph seemed happy enough with me at the time."

"Ah, Slicer, beggars can't be choosers, is the thing. Give me a proper dwarven girl, all plush an' pillowy, over your rock-hard abs any day. 'Course, the way you're eatin', you'll be a proper dwarven girl in no time flat."

Sam frowned. "Just 'cause I'm not countin' ever calorie doesn't mean I intend to get fat, and don't you forget it, ya skeevy beard-chaser. My metabolism can handle a little party now an' then."

"Oh, really?" Mike grinned wickedly, pushing a few errant strands of slick, dark hair out of his eyes. "Care to make a wager?"

Sam thought for a moment.

"Here's how we're gonna do it," Two-Bits Mike said, putting an arm around Sam's shoulders and leaning in close as if he were discussing a bank heist rather than a perfectly legal wager. "You spend the rest of Brewfest here, puttin' away at least as much every day as you have already -- meanin' one or more of everythin', and four dozen mugs of beer at the minimum, an' pretty much anythin' else you can hold. At the end of the celebration, you get back into your workin' leathers, an' you win."

"What do I win?"

"I dunno. Hundred gold?"

"A hundred gold?" Sam snorted. "I'll spend that on food alone!"

"A thousand? Okay, a thousand and a half, final offer."

"Forget it. Didn't I tell you I'm richer than anythin' now? Nothin' you can offer is more'n a drop in the bucket for me."

"I think you can," Mike replied, "and once I win, you've gotta eat anythin' I tell you to eat during Hallows End, Pilgrim's Bounty, and Winter's Veil, three holidays your scrawny self has never appreciated. I'll have myself a nice round roly-poly dwarven lass to ring in the new year with!"

"I... I don't know about that..." Sam gulped.

"Worried your precious metabolism's gonna fail you? Well, if you want to give up and admit defeat now--"

"Never!" snapped Sam. "You're on, Two-Bits. Hope you enjoy you two bits hangin' out for all the bishops and priestesses to see. Shed a little Light on them, eh?"

"H-Hey come on Lil Lizz there isn't any need for violence" Mike gulped as he stared down the two barrels of the dwarven shotgun leveled at his face.

Though most gnomes were highly regarded for their forays into the often dangerous and reality-bending realm of Engineering, Lizzy "Lil Lizz" Sprigsprocket had chosen a less sensible path. She was renowned as Ironforge's most bizarre alchemist, focusing her talents not on making healing droughts or skill-enhancing elixirs, but on potions with often questionable effects. Potions that turned your hair green, potions that enhanced your treasure finding abilities (But only on the third Saturday of every month), and potions that caused you to swell up like a balloon. Two-Bits was banking on the fact that Lil Lizz might have something to help "grease the wheels." of his current project.

"I told you once Two-Bits, if I caught you setting foot in my shop after the last time, I'd paint the walls with your head." Lil Lizz yelled in a high pitched voice.

"Now hold on, can I really be blamed if your love potion, which was extremely effective and at a more than accommodating price I might add, would stir up such feelings for you?"

"And exactly what part of that potion was responsible for you stealing and fencing my alembic and my inventory of herbs after you wore me out in bed?" Lil Lizz cocked the hammer of her shotgun as she began to squeeze the trigger.

"Wait hold on, what if I told you I have a tidy sum of gold for your services!" Mike yelped in a last ditch effort to save his skin.

"Alright, that's a start." Lizz said as she lowered the gun. "Start talking pretty boy."

"Well I'm glad we can at least be sensible about this!" Two-Bits sighed in relief as he relaxed his posture. "You remember Slicer Slam, pretty young dwarf girl who I used to run with back in Stormwind?"

"Of course, I used to make designer poisons for her whenever she found some interesting herbs."

"Well I got me a little wager with her. This is her first Brewfest since she gave up the life of adventure and thieving, and she seems to think she's incapable of gaining on the dwarven diet. I aim to prove her wrong."

"So you're going to cheat like a horny goblin?"

"But of course! I just need something to unleash the proper dwarf in her, if you get my drift."

Lil Lizz thought for a second before it hit her. "I got what ya need right here Two-Bits." Lizz shuffled to the back of her store, throwing open a gigantic dresser filled with numerous vials, all bubbling in different bright flourscent colors. "This one right here should do it." The vial Lizz pulled out was a bright neon green, the concoction bubbled furiously in the contents of it's glass shell. The label simply read "Hog Fattener."
