1222122.content:
A groan escaped Sam's greasy lips as she hoisted herself into bed. She'd never eaten so much in her life. For nearly a week, Two-Bits had been stuffing her with carb-laden treats until she couldn't hold another crumb and pouring beer down her throat until she brimmed with it.

She could swear that she was getting fatter, too. She couldn't understand how she was putting it on so quickly, but she was sure it was true. Her arms felt -- softer. Fleshier. Her face looked a little bit rounder in the mirror. Some of that was probably due to plain old bloating, but she had to admit that not all of it was.

I need to exercise, she thought, but just the thought of moving gave her cramps. Ugh, this bet was a terrible idea...

It's a good thing I've got a backup plan.

She found herself being shaken out of a beer-soaked slumber by her midnight appointment, a goblin leatherworker named Tix Hidepilfer who was known to follow adventurers around and skin the beasts they killed.

"Hey! Slicer! There better be a good reason you called me all the way into Ironforge," he grumbled. "Any of those guards seen me, I'd be short a head."

"You're already short a couple feet," Sam smiled. "I wasn't worried. Your discretion is the reason I called you."

"And your recent good fortune is the reason I answered." His face split in a money-hungry grin. "Planning on adding a few upgrades to your gear? A nice anti-grav belt maybe, or maybe a flame tosser, or -- I know! A pair of knocker-mounted chest bazookas! All yours, for the right price."

"Nothin' like that," Sam said, waving him away. "I just need it... altered."

"Altered how?"

"Let out, okay?" she snapped.

"Oh-ho," Tix chuckled. "I thought I noticed something different about you. So, the old Slicer is letting herself go, eh? Thinking of changing your name to Thunderbuns?"

"No, and if you call me that again, you'll have to get out of Ironforge naked and wearing your ears as a moustache. Can you do it or not?"

"Calm down, sugar bulges. I can do anything."

"Good, because there's a complication. It's currently being kept in a secure vault owned by a friend of ours."

"What? And may I ask why?"

"Because apparently Two-Bits doesn't trust me not to cheat!"

"Ha! The nerve of some fellas, huh?" Tix smiled. "So how much you want me to let this out?"

"Not too much. It can't be baggy, or he'll get wise. Just... an inch or two on the thighs, maybe three on the waist, and a little more room in the cups. Got it?"

"Got it. One plus-size casing for a dwarven sausage coming up. Now, where exactly is this vault?"

-------

Fifteen minutes later, Tix found himself sliding down a Goblin Retractable Semi-Explosive Microcable into the back room of Lil Lizz's shop. Ah, he said, spotting the vault. He would have to work quickly. Judging by the still-steaming mug of coffee sitting on the workbench, Lil Lizz hadn't been gone long; she could be back at any moment.

His eyes narrowed as he saw the half-empty vial of green liquid sitting askew in the rack, with a receipt taped to it. Lil Lizz, I.O.U. 2gp for: 10cc Hog Fattener. Signed, Two-Bits.

Either our human friend has taken up farming on the side, Tix thought, or he's playing this just as dirty as Sam is. Well, ain't this a fun little friendly wager?

Suddenly, he heard tiny footsteps just outside the door. Lizz was coming back!

Oompah-pah, oompah-pah...

The usual cheerful horns seemed somehow weary; only a couple of days of Brewfest remained, and while a few dedicated souls continued to chug and chuck (and occasionally spew), many of Azeroth's citizens had gone back to their fields, shops, and barracks, nursing hangovers and muttering at the distant sound of the oompah-horn. The crowds had thinned, though the remaining individuals making them up had done quite the opposite -- including one little pink-haired gnome who was less little every day.

"So how's your -- munch -- target doing?" Lil' Lizz said, taking a big bite out of a sausage-and-butter sandwich. "Remember, no refunds if you don't win. Hog fattener is only guaranteed for use on hogs, pigs, boars, and assorted porcine outliers."

"Oh, no worries, no worries!" Two-Bits laughed. "Your little potion has been working like a charm. She must have put on twenty pounds since this business started. All it takes is a drop here and there in her brew when she's not looking and her appetite..."

He looked down at Lil' Lizz, who was just finishing off the sandwich and licking her lips free of crumbs. She'd been enjoying her food lately, and it showed. The girl was -- well -- rounding out all over quite deliciously.

"... her appetite does the rest -- say, Lizz, you haven't been inhaling that stuff while you work, have you?"

"What, do you think I'm stupid?" she snorted. "I wear a mask when I'm brewing dangerous stuff."

"The way you're packing it away, I'd check for leaks."

"Yeesh, can't a girl enjoy herself for once? It's Brewfest."

Two-Bits smiled. The little gnome was going to enjoy herself right out of her grease-stained overalls if she kept this up. Not that he minded; Lil' Lizz could stand to be a little cuddlier. And next to a plump dwarven lass, there was nothing better in the bedroom than a nice gnomish butterball. Afterwards, they made wonderful pillows.

------

Sam, meanwhile, was getting rather tired of beer and sausage and cheese. She'd been stuffing herself with it until she was purple in the face for almost two weeks now, after all, and every time she felt the laces of her Brewfest dress bind uncomfortably tight across her chest and back, it only reminded her how fat she was getting.

She sighed, pinching the creamy inner tube of pudge around her middle, which the dress was having a harder and harder time hiding. Ugh, I'm gross, she thought to herself miserably. It was a good thing she was good at sneaking; actually walking around in full view in public like this and she would have died of embarrassment.

Just two more days, she thought resolutely, taking a bite out of a large wheel of gouda. Two more days, and this is over -- and I'm going to run and jump and do sit-ups until I lose every ounce of this blubber!

Unless she lost.

And if she lost -- oh, it was horrible to think about -- if she lost, Two-Bits would hold her to it! He would force-feed her buckets of candy during Hallow's End, cram her with flocks of turkey during Pilgrim's Bounty, and finally, if there was any part of her body remaining that hadn't been fattened to his generous standards, he would spend all of Winter's Veil finishing her off with fruitcake.

She shuddered. The autumn wind suddenly felt as cold as winter.

1223.content:
A dwarven mage was a rare thing, especially in their capital city Ironforge. While most dwarfs were interested in treasure hunting or dragon slaying, their mages preferred a quieter life from behind the scenes. Some would manipulate matters in court, using their spells to gather influence and their intellect to impress nobles. Others, however, weren't so ambitious with their gifts in magic.

You were one such dwarf.

Your name was Zelda Bagshot. You had been born to a couple of hunters who had spent most of their lives living in the winter wilderness of Dun Morogh, only deciding to settle down in Ironforge after they had you. They opened up a tavern and you grew up living in the bar-room, listening to the stories of adventures and hearing about the world. But, most importantly, you grew up on ale. You were practically nursed on the stuff and by the time you were sixteen, you could drink four men under the table.

This was, in part, thanks to your magical gift you discovered on your own at an early age. When you turned ten, you discovered that you could move things with your mind and cast simple spells. However, instead of telling your parents so you could get a proper training, you kept your gift quiet and learned about controlling your powers on your own. They called dwarves like you hedge mages, but people had a different name for your now that you had turned twenty one.

"Wench!" called one of the adventurers who had visited your parent's pub. "Bring me more ale!"

Already an adult and you hadn't stepped out of your parent's home yet. But this never bothered you, as you enjoyed the stink of bar and the sounds of a pub. For your age, you were also incredibly beautiful and thin by dwarf standards. You didn't have the curves that most dwarven women were famous for, looking so much like a typical human save for your short stature. Most noticeable was your long fiery hair done up in two braids behind your head.

"Just a moment, hun," you said to your clearly tipsy customer. "You still haven't paid for your first few."

The ragged human looked cross with you now. "Don't give me any lip and fill my mug, stupid wench."

You knew better than to lose your temper with a drunk, and this was exactly the sort of man you had been looking for. "Fine, tell you what. I'll give you all the free ale you want, but you need to beat me in a drinking contest. If you lose, you need to put down twice what you owe for the drinks."

"Hah," the man pulled out two gold coins and slammed them on the table. "You're on!"

You smiled and quickly brought out a handful of drinks, allowing the both of you to get to work. By the third sip of beer, you had gathered the attention of everyone in the tavern as they watched.

Your opponent kept on drinking, never once realizing that you had been transferring a large portion of each of your cups into his own tankard with magic. By your tenth glass, he was already struggling to even sit up straight. In a couple of more chugs, he was out cold on the table.

You smirked at your success, barely even feeling tipsy from the few drinks you did have and snatched up the coins. "Thank you very much."

Most of the patrons returned to their own drinks as you left your sleeping victim at the table with a half-fill tankard still stuck in his hand. But in the shadows of the tavern was a pair of eyes looking at you. They belonged to...
1223.title: The Wench

12231.content:
You carried on with your day unaware of the pandaren that had planted himself in the corner of the tavern, eyeing you up like a predator did while hunting. But every time you shot a glance in his direction, you saw him looking away from you even though you knew he was still watching. Eventually, you put away the gold you had won from your gambling in a cabinet and confronted the staring panda-man.

"You have a problem?"

He blinked a few times and spoke in his people's typical accent. "Pardon?"

"You've been staring at me since I drank that loudmouth under the table. Don't think I haven't noticed. What's your deal?"

The pandaren seemed surprised but then calmly smiled. He looked like many of his kin, with black and white fur on a pudgy body with gigantic potbelly. However, his fur was very faded and grey, to suggest that he was an older gentleman. Most oddly of all though was the giant scar along his eyebrow.

"Ah, I'm sorry, good maiden. I was simply pondering how you did that magic trick before."

You felt a pang of annoyance. "What trick?"

"Oh, come now. I know magic when I see it. You fooled that poor gentlemen into believing that he had drunk the same amount as you, but in reality you kept refilling his cup with your own liquor."

With a huff from your nose, you shot your nastiest scowl at him. "You can't prove anything."

"No," replied the pandaren as he adjusted himself in his seat. "But I don't think the other patrons will trust your shop after they hear some rumors of the matron cheating them out of their coin."

You never took kindly to threats, but in the back of your mind you knew that those rumors would eventually cause your parents some trouble. "Alright then, I'll play your game. What do I have to do to keep you quiet?"

The pandaren smiled. "Well, I can see you're a aspiring young mage. I'm curious as to why someone with your talents is busy serving drinks in a small tavern."

"Just to pay rent while I live with my parents."

"A lovely lady your age living with her parents? Do you not dream of adventure?"

You thought back to all back the stories you heard from travelers and shrugged them off. "It's not for me."

"Why not? You have the potential to be a great wizard, you know."

"Not interested," you sighed.

"Mm," the great pandaren stroked his chin. "Well, nevertheless, to keep me quiet you'll have to beat me in one of your drinking games. And this time, no cheating."

"Very well," you reached over for another chair and table to put in front of the pandaren. "I'll just have to get some ale and..."

"No, no, that won't be necessary. We'll be using my ale."

You watched as he reached around the leather pouch next to his hip and produced a fat jug with a paw symbol on it in red.

She narrowed your eyes, having never tried pandaren ale before, but calmly replied. "You're on."
12231.title: Panda Brew

122312.content:
"Excellent," replied the old pandaren as he poured both you and him a cup of the ale. "Now, the rules are going to be quite simple. This will be a race to see who can down twenty shots the fastest."

"Twenty? Easy enough," you smirked as you raised the cup to your nose to get a sniff.

In an instant, you jolted your face away from the liquid. Your nostrils were suddenly on fire from smelling the stuff. Whatever was inside the cup had a burning and foul scent to it. The pandaren noticed the discordance on your face and laughed.

"I should warn you, this ale is very strong. Even for pandaren standards."

"It smells like vinegar!"

Continuing to chuckle, the pandaren swirled the cup around in his hand. "Are you chickening out?"

You scowled at him and braced yourself for the first shot. "Never."

Closing your eyes, you tilted your head back and downed the drink. It tasted almost as bad as it smelled, but when you opened your eyes, you saw that the pandaren was already pouring himself another glass. You quickly followed suit to match the pace.

After your second glass, you began to feel odd but you passed it off simply as a reaction from drinking such strong liquor. You were more focused on catching up to the pandaren, who was on his fourth drink, to notice but the second glass had brought with it some...changes to you. Specifically with your ears which had migrated their way to the top of your head.

As you continued the drinking game, the more changes your body took. In fact, after each shot, a different part of your body morphed into something different. The second shot transformed your nose black and snout-like, similar to a bear's. The third caused your teeth to grow sharp. The fourth sprouted a stubby tail directly above your butt.

But no matter how quickly you downed the glasses, the pandaren was always one step ahead of you. You were so focused on the competition that you didn't even notice the changes done to your body by the ale.

As the pandaren finished his eighth, he sighed. "Shall I slow down for you?"

You quickly chugged your sixth shot, causing several spots of brown fur to sprout from your hands. "Don't gloat, this isn't over yet."

As the drinking game went on, the changes grew even more wild to the point where it was almost ridiculous that you didn't notice them. But you couldn't help it, something about the ale and the competition made blind to everything else around you. It was a good thing that you both had started this contest in the dark corner of the bar or people might have stared at your transformation.

The seventh drink caused your hands to shape into large paws. The eighth did the same to your feet and sharp claws began to poke their way out of your leather boots. The ninth caused your nose and mouth to push out more like a snout.The tenth gave you more teeth and extended both your claws and tail further out. Once you got into the double digits, though, things got more interesting.

The effects of the alcohol were starting to hit you, making you feel lightheaded. This helped you get distracted by the effects of the eleventh drink which made you grow several inches taller and wider. You were never a pudgy dwarf, so the extra weight caused your normally loose blouse and skirt to suddenly feel a little tighter. Drinks twelve and thirteen furthered this growth as your girls puffed up from their non-existent AA's to BB, then CC. In addition, your thighs were now straining your skirt by the seams and you had now gained a foot in new height, causing the bar around you to look a lot smaller.

At drink fourteen, the pandaren stopped and said. "Maybe we should stop."

"No," you hiccuped. "I'm going to catch up to you."

Fifteen caused another growth spurt but also made more fur grow from your arms and legs, taking on the same chestnut color as your hair. By drink sixteen you no longer looked like a dwarf woman but a young, if short, pandaren girl. Seventeen, you had caught up to the male pandaren and were finishing growing fur. Eighteen caused your head to reshape itself into a bear-like appearance and your vision became darker. You were beginning to black out.

Nineteen, your tail had finished growing and you looked exactly like a red panda pandaren, even passing the six foot height mark and still growing. Drink twenty came and...

After a hard day of questing and protecting Bloodhoof Village from the Venture Company. You decide to explore around abit.
132.title: Enter the Tauren woman.

1322.content:
Bloodhoof Village was never short on visitors from the Barrens. Being the last stop before Thunderbluff, travelers from all over often stopped there to trade and promote business growth. This brought all sorts of interesting characters to interact with the tauren, and you had often bought rare supplies from them. But today was a slow day it seemed, the only visitor in the village seemed to be a traveling potion maker trying desperately to sell elixirs to anyone who passed by him. He was a goblin though, and his kind were not normally trusted especially by your people. They cared little for the troubles of others and greed often caused them to clash with the nature loving tauren. But curiosity got the better of you and you went over to see what he was selling.

"Come on come on! Get them while they're hot! Goldenpot's Precious Potions! Come one, come all!"

You cleared your throat to get his attention.

"Wha-? Oh hello up there my lovely lady! Can I interest you in some of my finest potions?!"

"Perhaps..." you said, "What sort of elixirs are you selling, goblin?"

"Oh I got just what you need my tauren friend! Here look at this...."
1322.title: There's a traveling potion maker in the vil...

13222.content:
"This here is a Diminishing Potion. They're used by the night elves to shrink overgrown trees. One whiff of this will make you lose several inches! You look a little on the tall side, so I figured maybe someone like you could use it."

You glared down at him, causing him to yelp slightly and put his hands up to mean he meant no offense. Normally you would have flattened the goblin for his brash comments. But the potion sounded interesting to you. Most potions you used were the kinds that healed or cured you. You had no idea there were potions with such uses. There where more than a handful of times you could recall where your size had been an issue and cost you a good hunt.

"Do the effects wear off, goblin?"

"Of course they do eventually. After twenty four hours usually. I poured some on my cousin Bilbo once and boy was it a hoot! In fact he..."

The goblin droned on with his story, leaving you to return to your own thoughts. You definitely wanted the potion. Aside from it's practical uses, something struck you making you almost longing for it. You wanted to see what would if you guzzled do the whole thing and were tiny for a day. You were curious what it would be like to be small so to speak.

"So do we have a deal my tauren friend?"

"Err..." ,he broke you from your fantasy world, "How much is it?"

"Normally I sell this for a gold piece. But considering you look like you need this badly...50 silver pieces!"

There would go your earnings from your last hunt. But you took Goldenpot's offer. He handed you a clear vial with a light blue liquid. You had doubts this thing would even work, so you thought maybe it would be a good idea to test a little bit of it now...
13222.title: The Diminishing Potion.

132222.content:
By the look of fear in the goblin's eyes, you could tell that he wouldn't dare double cross someone like you. Worst case, you could track him down and make him pay for deceiving you. Besides, something about the potion's look made you believe this was the real deal. You gently placed the bottle into your pack and headed for Thunderbluff to meet with a friend of yours.

She was a black haired tauren by the name of Grenda Halfhoof. She was an alchemist herself, who spent much of her time with her head in old books searching for recipes. Physically she was a good foot smaller than you and was much less fit for fighting or hunting, so she contributed to the tribes through her talent with potions. She always had a few new strength or health potions for you to use on your journeys.

As you ascended on the elevator into the trade part of town, you had a good idea.

"Maybe Grenda can take a look at this for me." you said to yourself while taking another look at the vial, "She would be able to see if Goldenpot was lying or not."

You made your way to Grenda's shop near the auctioneers. She was busy sweeping the ground with a broom, trying to make her store look presentable. She didn't even notice you approach her until you were right next to her.

"Oh Shala!" she said, almost dropping her broom, "Sorry I didn't even see you there!"

"Long time no see Grenda." you said with a warm smile. Grenda motioned you into her tent to have a seat with some tea. You followed her and caught up on the local news.

"So they're moving the Horde forces to Northrend? Perhaps I should enlist.", you said, taking a sip of the herbal tea, " By the way Grenda, I happened to stop by a vendor on the way here who had a strange potion that I purchased. Since it was your area of expertise, I thought you should take a look at it considering the merchant was an untrustworthy goblin."

"You always run into the strangest people Shala." she replied as you handed her the bubbling container. "Did he say what he thought it was?"

"Yes, a shrinking potion of all things. Do you have any idea if he was lying?"

She stared at the vial, before opening it to sniff the liquid. She shook her head and said. "There's no way to know the effects unless you drink it. It's not poisonous though, so that's always a plus."

Grena handed you the vial back after putting the cap on. You held it up to get a good look at it. "I'll drink it then, unless you want to."
132222.title: Your friend, Grenda Halfhoof

choices: You shrink to less than a foot.
1322221.content:
Grenda had a particular look on her face. It was like she was hiding something from you, and her eyes didn't dare break from the potion. You raised your eyebrows and gave her a concerned look until she noticed that you were trying to get her attention.

"Wha? Oh, sorry Shela. No, I think you should be the one to do it. You bought it after all."

You frowned. Grenda wasn't one to pull tricks, especially on one of her friends. So you shrugged your shoulders and opened the cap of the bottle. A little sip of it wouldn't hurt you, right? You brought the vial to your mouth and drank in a spoonful of the fizzing liquid. It tasted like bananas almost. Maybe a bit more stronger. You brought the potion down and stood up to see if there were any effects. You waited for any slight change, but nothing happened for a whole minute. You smirked at Grenda.

"I guess he was a liar after all."

Then you felt something. It was like the contents in you stomach were traveling throughout your body. It wasn't painful, it was just tingly. Almost like butterflies were crawling in your fur. Grenda stared at you with raised eyebrows and eyes fill of interest.

"Something wrong?" She asked.

"I just feel really weird," You replied. "Bubbly...Like the potion. It's probably nothing."

Then another feeling traveled within you. It was like a small tremor or a wave that moved in your body like a ripple in a pond of water. Suddenly Grenda seemed a little less shorter than you. That wasn't all, your clothes were a tad looser but only slightly.

"You just shrunk about an inch," Grenda replied with a smile as she stood up to compare height.

It was true. While you normally towered over her, it seemed like she had grown a thumb's length in height. But in reality the potion had made you shorter.

"Wow, looks like we were wrong," You said, pulling with your now looser pants.

The tremor feeling returned again. This time you saw the changes in height lose. Your eye sight jolted down and your clothes grew ever looser. While the last one had been a mere inch, this change was twice that. You now stood under 7 feet, having lost three inches of your height! You looked at Grenda with panic.

"I'm shrinking even more!"

"I know, when I looked at the potion I realized that it was quite potent," She answered with a mischievous smirk.

You were about to say "What?!", but another quake-like feeling rumbled throughout your body. Your form shriveled down in height much worse this time. It had been four inches! You were 7 inches smaller than when you walked in the hut! Your pants had fallen off your waist, but thankfully your tail had caught them. Grenda was looking bigger and bigger by the moment. It wouldn't be long before she passed you in height! You were starting to get scared and you pulled up your pants to cover your exposed lower half.

"If my calculations are correct," Said Grenda. "You should lose eight inches next time."

"Grenda...W-why?"

She smiled playfully. "I'm just tired of you boasting about your height Shela. It gets tiring after awhile hearing how 'great' and 'powerful' you are while hunting. Maybe this little change will help you have some humbleness in your attitude from now on."

You reached out for her to stop this but the dreaded rumbling feeling in your gut returned again. Down you went, losing eight inches in height. Suddenly, you weren't looking down at Grenda. You were looking up!

For some reason your body didn't want to obey your commands. Perhaps it was because the potion had some sort of spell that ceased your movements. Or more likely, you were scared beyond all belief. Grenda was right, your height was something you were very proud of. Losing it slowly like this while watching the world grow around you was paralyzingly frightening. You shivered as you huddled in your growing clothes for comfort. Your pants were already on the floor, and your shirt was covering your body like a small dress.

"Grenda...P-please stop this..."

"Sorry Shela, you know there's nothing I can do now. The potion will just have to run it's course for twenty four hours. You'll be back to normal before you know it, so just enjoy it."

Easy for her to say. Everything was so surreal now, you felt like you were going to throw up. But you realized that the sick feeling in your stomach was really another quake feeling. You braced yourself to lose sixteen inches this time. This would bring you to down to under five feet! You dropped like the elevators in Thunderbluff. You eyesight lowered from Grenda's face to her chest and mid section. Your shirt could now completely cover you like a blanket. In an odd sort of way, you felt like a child again. Grenda seemed to think this as well, she squealed in delight and patted you on the head.

"Awww," She said with an obnoxiously cute voice. "Aren't you just the most precious little thing ever?"

"T-this isn't funny Grenda! What if I s-shrink away into nothing!?"

"Oh don't worry silly, you didn't drink nearly enough potion for that. In fact I wouldn't be surprised if it started to slow down now."

You were about to give a nasty retort but you felt the feeling in your belly yet again. Closing your eyes, you expected to drop thirty two inches this time. When you opened them, you discovered that while you had shrunk again it was a much smaller amount. But it was still large enough to make a difference! You were nearly below three feet now!

"See? Only eight inches that time. It's going back down."

"Oh yes...," You crossed your arms. "That's REAL comforting."

The process continued, you lost four inches the next time. Then two again. And finally one inch. Words could not express how relieved you were to be done with this nightmare. Little did you know, the nightmare was just beginning. Being now barely three feet in height, Grenda loomed over you like a giant. Without warning, she scooped you up with both arms like you were a baby.

"Hey! What in the name of the Earthmother are you doing Grenda!" You screamed as you flailed in her hands.

"You are just so cute like this Shela! I can't resist." She gave you a massive hug.

"Y-you can't just treat me like a toy!"

"Oh pipe down..."

"Oh pipe down...I'll be joining you down there in a moment." She said with a grin.

She reached over to the table and grabbed the potion which you had left up there before you started shrinking. She still had you in her arms as she popped open the cork. You were growing very concerned.

"Grenda! Don't do it!"

"Relax, will you Shela," Spoke Grenda as she grabbed a small glass off the table. "I'm drinking less than you did so that way I'm still the taller one."

Pouring a small amount into the cup, she hummed merrily. Somehow you thought she was enjoying this too much to take it seriously. She brought the glass to her mouth. The distinct smell of bananas reached your nose. There was barely a few drops of the potion in the glass. Grenda smiled but never released you from her grasp. In an instant, she chugged the entire contents.

"Cheers. See you down there Shela."
132222112.title: Two Tiny Tauren.

Grenda wiped her lips and set the glass down, eagerly awaiting for the shrinking to begin. You were still stuck in her arms when you felt the same rumbling feeling you had experienced when you drank the potion resonating from her. Something was wrong though. Instead of shrinking merely an inch in height, Grenda began to drop rapidly in size. Her clothing loosened and the straps from her shirt fell off her shoulders. She nearly dropped you as she tried to pull up her blouse.

The poor girl was near tears at this point, she was eye to eye with you now. "L-look in my potion cabinet! Maybe I can find an antidote!"

Her expression of terror neatly mirrored your own when you had gone through with the same shrinking process. She practically was swimming in her own clothing at this point. You had to resist the temptation to pick her up, like she did you. Down she went...Two feet...One foot eight.....One foot four....And finally, she stopped at the one foot marker. She looked so tiny to you. You were three times her height now after all.

You stepped over Grenda, who cowered into her clothing for comfort. "Now what shall we do with you?"
1322221122.title: Revenge is sweet.

All you could hear were her muffled cries as she kicked furiously to try to escape. No such luck, kodo could eat things much larger than her with ease. She would not be able to escape from this. In one giant gulp Grenda was swallowed completely whole!

Besides, the great tribal city of the tauren has always been a nice getaway. You nod to yourself silently, and let out a sigh, crossing the bridge across the Stonebull Lake, and into the empty rolling plains of Mulgore.

The journey isn't particularly long, since you're only walking about ten miles, and on a Kodo no less. After an hour under the light of An'she, the sun, you find yourself at the western elevators into the great Bluffs. You dismount and stand besides your trusted mount, readjusting your war harness, and pulling up your leggings slightly, letting your tail slide through the opening more easily.

You could never explain it but somehow you found the idea of changing forms strangely interesting. Maybe it was the fact that you're a short gnome with grand visions of greatness. Still business for the such creations is very poor and thus you often have to scarp by with used parts. Your shop is in the Dwarven District of the city of Stormwind.

You had to punch the controls to start it up but eventually the machine hummed to life. For "form selected" you clicked random, even if you came out a horrible mutated mess you could at least justify it this way. You stepped on the pad and were hit with a bright blue beam of light.

It was Sally Bronzebutton, a cute little girl gnome whom you had a big crush on but were too shy to ask out.

"Oh hey Glen." she said, "How goes business?"

"Nonsense. I am rested well enough and ready to return. Let us go now."

The night elf raised a palm in the air as if to grasp something. After a few seconds of focusing, he seemed to have grasped something in the air and was pulling on it. An eerie blue light began to emanate from the center of his hand.

"Take my free hand, Flintsocket."

The gnome quietly obeyed and felt herself being yanked forward as if someone was squeezing her through a very tight hole. Time and space seemed to warp past her as she was sent flying forward. The last thing she remembered was landing on something hard...

~

"...still she shows some promise...I will inspect her when she awakes."

Val groaned slightly and rose from a bed which she had somehow landed in. That's when she realized that she was no longer in the cold comfort of her gnomish home but somewhere far more foreign and nature based.

The bed she was in was mostly made of leaves and bark, but was still oddly comfortable and warm. The room she was in appeared to be some sort of hollowed out stump. She didn't have time to observe all of her surroundings as a tall robed figure appeared in the doorway.

"Welcome, Flintsocket, to Moonglade. You have my thanks for saving my pupil from certain death."

The night elf laughed, Val saw that he had a large white beard suggesting an old. "Indeed, young Tork knows how to quickly get around the world. It was why we chose him for his mission. Anyway, I understand you came here to learn. An odd request, especially coming from the younger races."

"Regardless..." Val said firmly, stepping out of bed to make herself seem determined. "I'd like to be taught, for I'm more than willing to listen."

The old night elf laughed heartily. "Impressive will. Very well, since you've granted us a favor I see it fit as to honor your request. But first you must choose which path you would start on by which being you'd like to learn from..."

It looked almost like one of the moonwells your people used, but there was something very odd about it's surroundings. Everything in the clearing looked overgrown. Grass blades seemed like giant swords poking out of the ground. You could almost not see the tops of the trees in the area they had grown so high. Any living thing near the water was gigantic.

Feeling perplexed by this wondrous display of nature, you slowly approached the gushing waters knocking away the tall grass as it tickled your arms. Even the bugs flying around were the size of your head as you ducked narrowly missing one that whizzed by. You reached the marble stone of the fountain and peered over the ledge. The waters were a deep light blue color, bits of magic sparkled in the air all around it. You spotted a small golden plate at the top of the marble which you read out loud.

"The Fountain of Growth. By Elune! What an amazing discovery. A sample must be taken to the Arch-Druids!"

You shifted through your pack and produced a small clear vial to contain the water. Leaning over, you reached into the sparkling waters to take a tiny sample...

"Gotcha..."

You swiftly swooped into the fountain with your vial and pulled out with the small sample you desired. The crystal clear water glimmered in the tiny container as you eyed it with fascination. Unfortunately, you had been wandering the forest for quite some time now without a break. The curiosity in your eyes quickly turned into a thirsty look.

"Mrroww?" growled your moonsaber mount, Hushdawn. It was almost as if he had sensed what you were considering doing.

"Oh, come now Hushdawn," you turned to your feline friend. "We've explored the forests for hours now. One little sip of this water isn't going to kill me, I can sense the purity in this water. Perhaps it's even more taint-less than the waters that feed Hyjal."

"Grrowww..."

"I promise...Nothing bad is going to happen from one little drink. You can even have a sip, if you'd like."

Having convinced yourself, you tilted yours head back and chugged the sample. A rush of coolness like an early morning breeze tickled down your throat and into your stomach, along with a strange bubbly feeling that seemed to permeate your insides. That was perhaps the most refreshing drink you had ever had, you felt completely recharged now.

Now that you had drunk your sample, you quickly refilled your vial with another one which you safety stored in your backpack.

At first you thought it was the saddle pinching your stomach, but upon closer inspection you saw that it was your belt digging into you. Above it was a slight muffin top which caused some slight worry to you. You motioned for Hushdawn to stop running so you could step off and readjust yourself.

"What the...How did this happen?"

As your feet touched the ground, you noticed something else as well. You were beginning to feel slightly lighter on your feet than you had been before. Wasting no more time, you quickly undid your leather strap to free your compressed stomach. In an instant, your purple belly surged forward now that it was no longer being contained, it was then you realized just how much it had grown.

"By Elune! I can't even see my feet anymore!"

It came to your attention that your stomach wasn't the only thing being affected by what you could only assume was the water. Every part of your body, from your breasts, to your thighs, to your butt, and even to your fingers, had puffed up in the last half an hour. It wasn't extremely significant, more like you had decided to pig out for all of Brewfest and earned a little pudge as a result. Only this wasn't fat that was covering your body, it was too light and didn't cause any sagging.

Between several deep breathes, you felt a slight tickle resonate within your stomach. It rose up from the breath in, but didn't return to its original size on the breath out. You were still growing!

"Fel...I must hurry then." You threw yourself on top of Hushdawn with a surprisingly less amount of weight than you expected. You had to reach the town and fast if you wanted to counter whatever this was.

As Hushdawn dashed along the path with long, leaping strides, you kept your mouth clamped shut and breathed in only the smallest, shallowest breaths you could. With one last series of jumps, Hushdawn leapt from a precipice, bounded from branch to branch, and landed gracefully in the middle of Astranaar. You slid off his back. Normally you were an excellent rider, but today you felt off -- and bouncing all the way here on his back hadn't helped things. You felt as though you needed to burp, but nothing came out. Ugh. They said Elen has some human ancestry in her somewhere -- it was impossible, of course, but it would explain her under-six-foot height, her skin -- which was a pale just-barely-lavender instead of a rich purple -- and her impulsive nature. She grabbed you in one of her trademark bear hugs and squeezed. Normally, you didn't mind her hands-on attitude, but the pressure made you feel unpleasant.

"Well," she said, "look at you! I haven't seen you in weeks. You look -- uh --"

She looked you up and down, and you could almost see the realization popping into her head. Wow, Freia's getting fat.

"Unnh!" Oola turned and flung a rock in frustration. It bounced off one of the moss-covered Stranglethorn trees, nearly brained her on the way back, and smacked into the straw training dummy. Oola's jaw dropped.

The first time I hit that stupid thing all day, and it's by mistake!

Oola had sent spears into trees, into the ground, into the river, into distant huts, into a zeppelin which was passing overhead, and several times into her own feet -- if she were anything but a quick-healing troll, she would have crippled herself five times over. She'd even managed to send spears into previously thrown spears which were stuck in odd spots where she couldn't recover them.

The sad thing was, she wasn't even the worst shot in the tribe. Whoever'd named them the Wildspear probably hadn't meant it as a compliment. She'd really thought that with enough practice, she'd be able to achieve basic competence, though.

Now, in some troll tribes, the daughters of the chieftain are pampered and waited upon hand and foot, filled with food and drowned in drink until they're nothing but balls of blubber, the better to show off the chieftain's wealth. In other tribes, the chieftains' daughters are great warriors in their own right, trained in the arts of fighting and hunting, and sculpted into musclebound Amazons who can cleave a dwarf in two with a single stroke.

The Wildspear tribe wasn't like either of those. Oola was no soft princess or chiseled champion. She was just a skinny teenager. In fact, she was such a beanpole that, more than once, her loincloth had slipped off her lack-of-hips in the middle of an important ceremony, causing her blue skin to turn purple with embarrassment as she accidentally mooned the elders. Pimply skin and tusks that hadn't come in straight only added to the gawk factor.

She had to do something, and soon. The tribe wasn't strong enough to survive on its own, and if she distinguish herself, she'd end up married off to the son of some equally tiny and desperate tribe. The Noseroot, maybe, or the Slobbertusk, or even (shudder) the Bloodfarts.

No -- she would make a name for herself or die trying. She picked up the rock (it had served her better than the spear, anyway) and walked into the forest, resolve she would only come back when she deserved to. It wasn't long before she came to a crossroads on the jungle path.

One branch led downwards, towards the eastern shore. Jaguero Isle wasn't more than a quick swim away. It was rumored that immense apes wandered through the fruit-laden forests of the island, ripe for the hunting. Perhaps if she returned with a trophy, she would prove herself.

Another branch let north into the mountains. There, in the misty high reaches, lived the Stumblefist Ogres, clumsy brutes who were as pathetic among ogrekind as the Wildspear were among trolls. Still, one had to start somewhere, and slaughtering a few ogres was definitely a start.

A third branch headed south, towards Booty Bay. All kinds of strange things, from lands so far off she could barely imagine how long it would take to walk there, could be found in that mysterious place. Maybe one of those clever little green creatures which swarmed all over that wooden honeycomb could solve her problem.
